terms.definition: A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to access previous versions and maintain an audit trail of revisions.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted remotely and accessed via the internet rather than installed locally.
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems.
Standard Operating Procedures - detailed written instructions that describe how to perform routine tasks or processes consistently and safely.
Enterprise Resource Planning - integrated software systems that manage and coordinate all business processes and data across an organization.
Internet of Things - a network of physical devices embedded with sensors and software that collect and exchange data over the internet.
A single, unified storage location where all organizational documents are stored, organized, and managed for easy access and consistency.
The ability for multiple users to simultaneously edit, comment on, and update documents with changes visible instantly to all participants.
The capability of software or documentation platforms to be fully functional and user-friendly on mobile devices like smartphones and tablets.
A chronological record of all changes, access, and activities performed on documents or systems, used for compliance and security purposes.
The ability of software to display content and interface elements in multiple languages to accommodate global teams and users.
A maintenance strategy that uses data analysis and monitoring to predict when equipment will need maintenance before failures occur.
Official records and documents that demonstrate adherence to industry regulations, safety standards, and legal requirements.
Digital documentation that includes clickable elements, multimedia content, and dynamic features to enhance user engagement and understanding.
The problematic scattering of related documents across multiple locations or systems, making information difficult to find and manage efficiently.
